title: Glyph piracy?
content:
see [http://typophile.com/node/58725](http://web.archive.org/web/20090809181610/http:/typophile.com/node/58725 "http://typophile.com/node/58725") (scroll down)

Theunis de Jong: <cite>“[…] to create this capital open e […], using pilferaged parts of another typeface ...”</cite>

Would you mind to tell us from which font you took those parts?
author: Andreas Stötzner

comments.content:
The short story is that the plain text for the article is in Minion, so I used the end cap serifs from its uppercase ’C’.  
A longer version is in [http://www.typophile.com/cms/node/48851](http://web.archive.org/web/20090809181610/http:/www.typophile.com/cms/node/48851).

I don’t modify my Minion, I have a separate font for the IPA symbols (touching on [Font licenses that allow private modifications?](http://web.archive.org/web/20090809181610/http:/typophile.com/node/58688); I would consider this a highly related issue). A separate font is a bit of a hassle in everyday use, but I’m not too keen on trying to improve on Slimbach.

It has been suggested I should use open source fonts for just the IPA characters, but — as you rightly remark in your other thread — these IPA characters appear in otherwise regular phrases. Admittedly, an alternative would be to set the entire text in the same (open source) font. (Not that I have that option, realistically.)
